text: Hello everyone, I am asking this question on a friend behalf. Is it advisable to message a interviewer who promised to get back to the applicant two weeks ago but hasn't to know her fate on the job status?

elements.text: Hello everyone, I am asking this question on a friend behalf. Is it advisable to message a interviewer who promised to get back to the applicant two weeks ago but hasn't to know her fate on the job status?

text: Yes. You can ask for updates on the interview process.

elements.text: Yes. You can ask for updates on the interview process.
Thank you

text:
Personally, I think it depends. I have been a hiring manager for content roles and applied for them myself, and as long as they're in a dedicated section on your resume, I don't think there's anything wrong with including links to your most relevant and impressive samples. If fact, it makes it easier to navigate to and review your pieces. Just make sure, as Erin said, to tailor the links you include to be relevant to the job you're applying for.

Another tip would be to make sure that you're using good anchor text and not just pasting in a long link. If you want to see if your links are getting clicked, you can also use a shortener like <http://Bit.ly|Bit.ly>. And, lastly, make links visually obvious so they're easy to recognize.

text: Thanks for your feedback! I appreciate it

elements.text: Thanks for your feedback! I appreciate it
No problem!

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"Since I've started working in tech, I've noticed that constant pivoting is a norm in this industry. From messaging to product names to even strategy and audience, the tech space is one of constant experimentation. 

While testing is essential when trying to understand how to best market and position the company, I also feel like pivoting all the time doesn't allow you to build anything. At times, it feels counterproductive, especially when you've created content that now feels like a waste of time and money because of the change in direction. 

So my question is, what advice do you have for someone to better navigate changes that impact the content and the content strategy. How does one build flexibility into the actual content piece and plan? "

As someone who has been in this situation multiple times, I think there’s an important distinction to make. Constant pivoting is the norm for _early stage tech startups that don’t have Product-Market fit_.

I want to call this out because I don’t think companies without solid PMF _can_ meaningfully engage in a content strategy for the reasons you named. If your core audience & product functionality is constantly changing, you lose all of the brand equity & momentum you’ve built up around certain topics. And then you’re stuck with all this noise in your sales pipeline post-pivot.

At this stage, the company should be investing mostly in product, engineering, and sales to find early clients/design partners to help the company find solid ground. They should not be heavily investing in content marketing, My opinion might be controversial here :sweat_smile:.

I would strongly consider whether this company is the best fit for your career goals at this time. You won’t be able to make the impact on the company you want with content (and as a result, your career) if they are still wrestling with PMF.

If you do decide to stay and you feel like your company is close to PMF, I would focus on content campaigns on themes you don’t envision changing.

For example, while the solution or product functionality (How to use X to do Y) might change, the industry & audience (engineers working in the data industry) you are targeting may not. So, focusing on building your brand as a voice that has its finger on the pulse of the industry (newsletters on industry trends, thought leadership) can build your brand equity without pigeonholing yourself with a certain end-user & functionality.

All that being said, I would still strongly recommend evaluating whether this company in its current stage is serving you as a content marketer. Good luck!

text:
1. Often (but not always, especially in startups; as <@U02BTBBH887> said, if your company is pivoting this much, they may not have the direction they need for a cohesive content strategy just yet), the founder/founding team will have a singular vision for the company, which should guide any changes/experiments that are going on. Align to this high-level vision as much as possible; it’ll act as an anchor of sorts while you’re navigating other changes. 
2. Lean on SEO content while your team is figuring out which direction they want to take — it’s hard to argue with the search data, and it’ll be useful content for your audience regardless of your current messaging. 
3. Update old content! The beauty of digital marketing is that everything can be easily updated and repromoted — salvage as much as you can by updating old content with new messaging/product names/etc. It’s a bit of a hassle, but it’ll prevent some of the waste (and most content should be updated periodically, regardless). 
4. If possible, try to get involved with any conversations that are happening regarding changes in messaging/strategy. At best, you can advocate for consistency and flexibility with the current content strategy (it might be helpful to bring SEO data, social conversations from your target audience, and content performance data to back up your case). At worst, you can keep up with the reasoning/thought process behind any changes and learn to anticipate and incorporate the opinions/perspectives of your team into your strategy moving forward.

Lean on SEO content while your team is figuring out which direction they want to take — it’s hard to argue with the search data, and it’ll be useful content for your audience regardless of your current messaging.

Update old content! The beauty of digital marketing is that everything can be easily updated and repromoted — salvage as much as you can by updating old content with new messaging/product names/etc. It’s a bit of a hassle, but it’ll prevent some of the waste (and most content should be updated periodically, regardless).

If possible, try to get involved with any conversations that are happening regarding changes in messaging/strategy. At best, you can advocate for consistency and flexibility with the current content strategy (it might be helpful to bring SEO data, social conversations from your target audience, and content performance data to back up your case). At worst, you can keep up with the reasoning/thought process behind any changes and learn to anticipate and incorporate the opinions/perspectives of your team into your strategy moving forward.

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"I have an interview coming up for a content manager role in the web development niche (broadly speaking). For those of you who have previously interviewed and hired individuals for a role like this, what questions should I be prepared for?

For context, this would be a second round interview. The first round was heavily focused on SEO and keyword research so I imagine there will be less of that in this round.

I've done a lot of reading and prepping already, but I want to make sure that I'm not missing anything. I'm trying to go into this as prepared as possible. Thank you for any guidance you might be able to provide. "

Hi all,

Experiencing an existential semi-crisis when it comes to marketing. I realized recently that I intensely dislike cold emailing people, traditional sales funnels and all manner of digital marketing that relies on "best practices" which are essentially all copies of each other that play on emotions and try to hook people with insincere language that leverages FOMO.

Has anyone had success with alternative options, perhaps a more personal approach to emailing (even if it doesn't scale) or even calling prospects instead? Have you ever tried getting clients without taking the "everybody does this so it must work" route?

Just trying to find something more (truly) personal and get off the hamster wheel of repetitive marketing.

elements.text:

Has anyone had success with alternative options, perhaps a more personal approach to emailing (even if it doesn't scale) or even calling prospects instead? Have you ever tried getting clients without taking the "everybody does this so it must work" route?

Just trying to find something more (truly) personal and get off the hamster wheel of repetitive marketing.
Absolutely nailed it.

text: If it makes ya feel better, what you described are “sales” activities, not marketing. So it makes sense why you would dislike it. You're a marketer. Not an SDR/AE.
